metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C# Booleans
C# Booleans
Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like:
content.html: Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like:

content.text: For this, C# has a bool data type, which can take the values true or false .
content.html: For this, C# has a bool data type, which can take the values true or false.

content.text: Boolean Values
A boolean type is declared with the bool keyword and can only take the values true or false :
content.html: A boolean type is declared with the bool keyword and can only take the values true or false:

content.code_html:
bool isCSharpFun = true;
bool isFishTasty = false;
Console.WriteLine(isCSharpFun);   // Outputs True
Console.WriteLine(isFishTasty);   // Outputs False

content.text: However, it is more common to return boolean values from boolean expressions, for conditional testing (see below).
content.html: However, it is more common to return boolean values from boolean expressions, for conditional testing (see below).

content.text: Boolean Expression
A Boolean expression returns a boolean value: True or False , by comparing values/variables.
content.html: A Boolean expression returns a boolean value: True or False, by comparing values/variables.

content.text: This is useful to build logic, and find answers.
content.html: This is useful to build logic, and find answers.

content.text: For example, you can use a comparison operator , such as the greater than ( > ) operator to find out if an expression (or a variable) is true:
content.html: For example, you can use a comparison operator, such as the greater than (>) operator to find out if an expression (or a variable) is true:

content.code:
int
x
=

10
;


int
y
=

9
;


Console
.
WriteLine
(
x
>
y
)
;

// returns True, because 10 is higher than 9
content.code_html:
int x = 10;
int y = 9;
Console.WriteLine(x > y); // returns True, because 10 is higher than 9

content.text: Or even easier:

content.code_html: Console.WriteLine(10 > 9); // returns True, because 10 is higher than 9

content.text: In the examples below, we use the equal to ( == ) operator to evaluate an expression:
content.html: In the examples below, we use the equal to (==) operator to evaluate an expression:

content.code:
int
x
=

10
;


Console
.
WriteLine
(
x
==

10
)
;

// returns True, because the value of x is equal to 10
content.code_html:
int x = 10;
Console.WriteLine(x == 10); // returns True, because the value of x is equal to 10
Console.WriteLine(10 == 15); // returns False, because 10 is not equal to 15

content.text: Real Life Example
Let's think of a "real life example" where we need to find out if a person is old enough to vote.
content.html: Let's think of a "real life example" where we need to find out if a person is old enough to vote.

content.text: In the example below, we use the >= comparison operator to find out if the age ( 25 ) is greater than OR equal to the voting age limit, which is set to 18 :
content.html: In the example below, we use the >= comparison operator to find out if the age (25) is greater than OR equal to the voting age limit, which is set to 18:

content.code:
int
myAge
=

25
;


int
votingAge
=

18
;


Console
.
WriteLine
(
myAge
>=
votingAge
)
;
content.code_html:
int myAge = 25;
int votingAge = 18;
Console.WriteLine(myAge >= votingAge);

content.text: Cool, right? An even better approach (since we are on a roll now), would be to wrap the code above in an if...else statement, so we can perform different actions depending on the result:
content.html: Cool, right? An even better approach (since we are on a roll now), would be to wrap the code above in an if...else statement, so we can perform different actions depending on the result:

content.code_html:
int myAge = 25;
int votingAge = 18;

if (myAge >= votingAge) 
{
  Console.WriteLine("Old enough to vote!");
} 
else 
{
  Console.WriteLine("Not old enough to vote.");
}

content.text: The boolean value of an expression is the basis for all C# comparisons and conditions.
content.html: The boolean value of an expression is the basis for all C# comparisons and conditions.

content.text: You will learn more about conditions ( if...else ) in the next chapter.
content.html: You will learn more about conditions (if...else) in the next chapter.
